answers.answer: Steroids and other health issues can affect blood sugar levels.While whole grain bread is better for you than white, it could still be increasing your blood sugar levels too much.Maybe you should reduce your bread intake and eat more vegetables and lean proteins and see if that helps bring your blood sugar levels down.  Since you're have trouble keeping your levels steady, you should be very careful to keep your diet as low on the glycemic index as you can.

Thanks Barb.  I know a little about low glycemic index, but I find Dr.Sears book really hard to read and understand. It is "Enter The Zone" and he has a PhD and writes like an intelectual, way about my pay grade.  I am on WW and have lost my weight that way, with walking for exercise.  I eat lean protein, veggies, and salads most of the time.  I love fruit, but limit it , to a day when I have carbs to spare.  As for the wheat bread, it is really hard to eat a sandwich without it.  I found some whole wheat/ black bean tortillas, and I make a wrap with that, instead of bread.   When I eat a hamburger, I order two small ones, and only use the tops of the buns which are less dense, and get double meat and veggies.  I know I have to stop eating things that hurt me, and I really am trying hard.  I've only known about my problem less than a year, and am trying to work my way through all the things I've been learning.

Congratulations on losing weight; I've recently been diagnosed with pre-diabetes, so I'm trying to control my diet in order to avoid full blown diabetes.There are a lot of articles on the internet that are very easy to understand about the low glycemic diet.  I can't get into someone who doesn't write so everyone can understand it.I limit fruit, as well, and when I do eat it, I try to stay with the ones that have the most fiber, such as apples, pears, cherries, etc.  I, too, remove the bun from burgers, but I don't get double meat, because there's typically too much fat in restaurant burgers.Here's a good article on glycemic diet: http://www.mayoclinic.com/health/glycemic-index-diet/MY00770There are many others, as well.  Simply google "low glycemic diet" and there will be a lot of articles that come up.  Some even give examples of where different foods rank in the glycemic index.We all have some difficulty getting used to new diets...... it hasn't been easy for me, either.

question: I eat hi carb foods, or low carb foods, and my blood sugar does not come down when I eat the low carbs, it stays in the 130-140 range even then.  I eat whole wheat bread, and sometimes do go to hi carb foods, and then it peaks up in the hi 160's.  I am on Trajenta, have lost 19 lbs, and walk 3-4 times a week.  Recently I had two injections of steroids, but it was two weeks ago, so I doubt that is the cause.  However, I am dealing with a number of health issues, and that is stressful, and I believe that is some of the root cause for the hi readings.  I will see my doctor next month and have blood work done.  With these hi readings I'm afraid my A1C will be up again, since it is the average over three months.
